009package imagingbook.spectral.dft;
010
011import org.jtransforms.fft.DoubleFFT_1D;
012import org.jtransforms.fft.FloatFFT_1D;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * FFT (fast) implementation of the DFT, based on the JTransforms package by
017 * Piotr Wendykier (see <a href="https://github.com/wendykierp/JTransforms">
018 * https://github.com/wendykierp/JTransforms</a>). Note that this class has no
019 * public constructor - instantiate sub-class {@link Dft1dFast.Float} or
020 * {@link Dft1dFast.Double} instead. See Sec. 18.4.2 of [1] for additional
021 * details.
022 * </p>
023 * <p>
024 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic
025 * Approach</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
026 * </p>
027 */
028public abstract class Dft1dFast extends Dft1dImp {
029        
030        private Dft1dFast(int size, ScalingMode sm) {
031                super(size, sm);
032        }
033        
034        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
035        
036        /**
037         * One-dimensional FFT implementation using {@code float} data. 
038         */
039        public static class Float extends Dft1dFast implements Dft1d.Float {
040        
041                private final float[] A;                // temporary array for FFT composed of re/im values
042                private final FloatFFT_1D fft;
043                
044                /**
045                 * Constructor using a specific scaling mode.
046                 * @param M the size of the data vectors
047                 * @param sm the scaling mode
048                 */
049                public Float(int M, ScalingMode sm) {
050                        super(M, sm);
051                        this.A = new float[2 * M];
052                        this.fft = new FloatFFT_1D(M);
053                }
054                
055                /**
056                 * Constructor using the default scaling mode.
057                 * @param M the size of the data vectors
058                 */
059                public Float(int M) {
060                        this(M, ScalingMode.DEFAULT);
061                }
062                
063                @Override
064                public void forward(float[] gRe, float[] gIm) {
065                        transform(gRe, gIm, true);
066                }
067                
068                @Override
069                public void inverse(float[] GRe, float[] GIm) {
070                        transform(GRe, GIm, false);
071                }
072                
073                @Override
074                public void transform(float[] inRe, float[] inIm, boolean forward) {
075                        checkSize(inRe, inIm);
076                        final float scale = (float) sm.getScale(M, forward);
077                        composeA(inRe, inIm, A);        
078                        if (forward)
079                                fft.complexForward(A);
080                        else
081                                fft.complexInverse(A, false);
082                        decomposeA(A, inRe, inIm, scale);
083                }
084                
085                // (re, im) -> A
086                private void composeA(float[] re, float[] im, float[] A) {
087                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
088                                A[2*i] = re[i];
089                                A[2*i + 1] = im[i];
090                        }
091                }
092                
093                // A -> (re, im)
094                private void decomposeA(float[] A, float[] re, float[] im, float scale) {
095                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
096                                re[i] = A[2*i] * scale;
097                                im[i] = A[2*i + 1] * scale;
098                        }
099                }
100        }
101        
102        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
103        
104        /**
105         * One-dimensional FFT implementation using {@code double} data. 
106         */
107        public static class Double extends Dft1dFast implements Dft1d.Double {
108        
109                private final double[] A;               // temporary array for FFT composed of re/im values
110                private final DoubleFFT_1D fft;
111                
112                /**
113                 * Constructor using a specific scaling mode.
114                 * @param M the size of the data vectors
115                 * @param sm the scaling mode
116                 */
117                public Double(int M, ScalingMode sm) {
118                        super(M, sm);
119                        this.A = new double[2 * M];
120                        this.fft = new DoubleFFT_1D(M);
121                }
122                
123                /**
124                 * Constructor using the default scaling mode.
125                 * @param M the size of the data vectors
126                 */
127                public Double(int M) {
128                        this(M, ScalingMode.DEFAULT);
129                }
130                
131                @Override
132                public void forward(double[] gRe, double[] gIm) {
133                        transform(gRe, gIm, true);
134                }
135                
136                @Override
137                public void inverse(double[] GRe, double[] GIm) {
138                        transform(GRe, GIm, false);
139                }
140                
141                @Override
142                public void transform(double[] inRe, double[] inIm, boolean forward) {
143                        checkSize(inRe, inIm);
144                        final double scale = sm.getScale(M, forward);
145                        composeA(inRe, inIm, A);        
146                        if (forward)
147                                fft.complexForward(A);
148                        else
149                                fft.complexInverse(A, false);
150                        decomposeA(A, inRe, inIm, scale);
151                }
152                
153                // (re, im) -> A
154                private void composeA(double[] re, double[] im, double[] A) {
155                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
156                                A[2*i] = re[i];
157                                A[2*i + 1] = im[i];
158                        }
159                }
160                
161                // A -> (re, im)
162                private void decomposeA(double[] A, double[] re, double[] im, double scale) {
163                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
164                                re[i] = A[2*i] * scale;
165                                im[i] = A[2*i + 1] * scale;
166                        }
167                }
168        }
169
170        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
171
172        /*
173         * Direct implementation of the one-dimensional DFT for arbitrary signal lengths.
174         * This DFT uses the same definition as Mathematica. Example:
175         * Fourier[{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8}, FourierParameters -> {0, -1}]:
176                {12.7279 + 0. i, 
177                -1.41421 + 3.41421 i, 
178                -1.41421 + 1.41421 i, 
179                -1.41421 + 0.585786 i, 
180                -1.41421 + 0. i, 
181                -1.41421 - 0.585786 i, 
182                -1.41421 - 1.41421 i, 
183                -1.41421 - 3.41421 i}
184         */
185
186        //test example
187//      public static void main(String[] args) {
188//
189//              System.out.println("******************** Float test (FFT) ********************");
190//              {
191//                      float[] re = { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 };
192//                      float[] im = new float[re.length];
193//
194//                      System.out.println("original signal:");
195//                      System.out.println("gRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
196//                      System.out.println("gIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
197//
198//                      Dft1d.Float dft = new Dft1dFast.Float(re.length);
199//                      dft.forward(re, im);
200//
201//                      System.out.println("DFT spectrum:");
202//                      System.out.println("GRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
203//                      System.out.println("GIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
204//
205//                      dft.inverse(re, im);
206//
207//                      System.out.println("reconstructed signal:");
208//                      System.out.println("gRe' = " + Matrix.toString(re));
209//                      System.out.println("gIm' = " + Matrix.toString(im));
210//              }
211//              
212//              System.out.println();
213//              System.out.println("******************** Double test (FFT) ********************");
214//
215//              {
216//                      double[] re = { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 };
217//                      double[] im = new double[re.length];
218//
219//                      System.out.println("original signal:");
220//                      System.out.println("gRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
221//                      System.out.println("gIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
222//
223//                      Dft1d.Double dft = new Dft1dFast.Double(re.length);
224//                      dft.forward(re, im);
225//
226//                      System.out.println("DFT spectrum:");
227//                      System.out.println("GRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
228//                      System.out.println("GIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
229//
230//                      dft.inverse(re, im);
231//
232//                      System.out.println("reconstructed signal:");
233//                      System.out.println("gRe' = " + Matrix.toString(re));
234//                      System.out.println("gIm' = " + Matrix.toString(im));
235//              }
236//      }
237
238}
